citeinfo.origin: Richard V. Lacouture, Benedict Estuarine Research Laboratory, Academy of Natural Sciences
citeinfo.title: Maryland Chesapeake Bay Water Quality Monitoring Program: Primary Productivity Component

pubinfo.publish: US E.P.A. Chesapeake Bay Program and Maryland Department of Natural Resources (program administered by Maryland Department of the Environment prior to July 1995 and subsequently Maryland Department of Natural Resources)

descript.abstract: The overall phytoplankton monitoring program is designed to detect and monitor changes in plankton production in relation to changing water quality conditions in Chesapeake Bay. Phytoplankton are the dominant producers in the Chesapeake Bay and are the base of the food chain for many higher tropic levels. Excessive blooms of plankton species are considered evidence of eutrophication in the bay and are known to degrade water quality and block light from submerged aquatic vegetation. Sampling is performed in conjunction with the Maryland phytoplankton, fluorometry, mesozooplankton, microzooplankton, jellyfish and water quality monitoring programs. Carbon fixation rates (C-14) were obtained from replicate surface layer composite samples at 16 stations in the Maryland portion of the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries. Samples were collected 18 times over the year, with monthly samples in October through March, and biweekly samples in April through September.
descript.purpose: The overall phytoplankton monitoring program is designed to detect and monitor changes in plankton production in relation to changing water quality conditions in Chesapeake Bay.
descript.supplinf: Information for this metadata was adapted from the Environmental Protection Agency Chesapeake Bay Program data page web site - www.chesapeakebay.net/data/index.htm. If above web sites change go to www.chesapeakebay.net.

cntorgp.cntorg: Interstate Commission on Potomac River Basin

cntinfo.cntpos: Chesapeake Bay Program Living Resources Data Manager
cntinfo.hours: 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Monday Through Friday

attracc.attraccr: Primary production samples are collected by a member of the Benedict Estuarine Research Laboratory plankton section. At the end of the sampling cruise, the samples are transferred to the C14 laboratory staff. Production and alkalinity measurements are made within twenty-four hours of sample collection. Chlorophyll a measurements are immediately frozen until analysis is performed. All Chlorophyll samples are processed within 2 months of sample collection.

dataqual.complete: Samples were collected 18 times over the year, with monthly samples in October through March, and biweekly samples in April through September. In January and February, the stations in the Choptank River and Baltimore Harbor are not sampled. After June, 1986 stations ET4.2 and EE3.1 were no longer sampled. Beginning in January 1996, there was no sampling done in February and November. Sampling was reduced to once a month in June and September. Sampling at Station CB1.1 was discontinued entirely.

methodid.methkey: Chesapeake Bay Program Analytical Method Code- PD101

method.methdesc: At the end of a sampling day, four 100 milliliters subsamples per station are decanted from the two surface-layer composite samples into sample-rinsed Pyrex milk dilution bottles (or polycarbonate bottles after July, 1989), one for time-zero C-14 blank (t0), one for alkalinity determination, and one from each composite for C-14 incubation. The two incubation samples per station are placed in a constant light incubator (>250 uE per sq m per sec) receiving running water from the study area for temperature control for an acclimation period >0.5 h. Then 1-2 uCi labeled NaHCO3 is added and samples are returned to the incubator for >1 h. After incubation, 15 ml is filtered through a 0.45 um membrane filter, rinsed with filtered sample water and fumed over concentrated HCl. Fifteen ml of t0 sample is similarly filtered and fumed. The filters are placed in scintillation vials and stored in a freezer.
Samples were collected 18 times over the year, with monthly samples in October through March, and biweekly samples in April through September.

procstep.procdesc: The following equations were used to determine the rate of carbon fixation in ug/l/hr. Note that the raw data used in these calculations are not presented in the associated data set. Only the resulting carbon fixation rate is included. 1) CARBALK = 12000 * (Total Alkalinity) 2) CARBFIX = IVOL * ((DPMSAM/FVOL)-(DPMT0/FVOL)) * CARBALK * 1.05 / DPMSP * (ETIME-BTIME) where CARBFIX = Carbon fixation rate in ug C/l/hr IVOL = Volume incubated; FVOL = Volume filtered DPMSAM = Disintegrations per minute from incubated sample; DPMT0 = Disintegrations per minute from corresponding unincubated (time zero - t0) sample DPMSP = Total; disintegrations per minute for C-14 spike; BTIME = Beginning time of incubation (h); ETIME = Ending time of incubation (h); CARBALK = Total inorganic carbonate from 1); Calculation of Assimilation Ratio; ASMRATIO = CARBFIX / CHLA - this ratio is calculated prior to rounding the CARBFIX value; where ASMRATIO = Assimilation ratio; CARBFIX = Carbon fixation in ug C/l/h from 2); CHLA = Chlorophyll a in ug/l.
